title-group.article-title: Repair of a palmar soft tissue defect of the proximal interphalangeal joint with a transposition flap from the dorsum of the proximal phalanx

abstract.p: This article describes the use of a transposition flap raised from the dorsum of the proximal phalanx for coverage of the volar defects at the proximal interphalangeal joint. The flap was based on the first dorsal branch of the proper digital artery. From January 2007 to March 2009, 14 digits in 14 patients (10 males and 4 females) were treated. There were 5 index, 6 middle, 2 ring, and 1 little finger. All patients underwent surgery 2–9 hours (mean 5 hours) after injury. Soft tissue defects ranged in size from 1.2 × 1.7 cm to 2.1 × 2.3 cm (mean 1.7 × 2 cm). Flap size ranged from 1.5 × 1.7 cm to 2.4 × 2.7 cm (mean 2 × 2.4 cm). Mean pedicle length was 1.1 cm (range 0.8–1.4 cm). All flaps completely survived. At final follow-up from 24–29 months (mean 26 months), mean active motion arcs of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints were 84° (range 75–91°), 86° (range 65–100°) and 54° (range 32–80°), respectively. Our technique is useful and reliable for coverage of a palmar defect over the proximal interphalangeal joint.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A traumatic soft-tissue defect on the palmar aspect of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint can result in functional morbidity. Although a transposition flap based on the second or third dorsal branch of the proper digital artery (PDA) can be used for reconstructing such a defect, an injury to the second and third branches may restrict use of the flap (Feng et al., 2011). In this article, we introduce a transposition flap based on the first dorsal branch of the PDA.

The first dorsal branch of the PDA gives blood supply to the dorsum of the proximal phalanx (Braga-Silva et al., 2005) (Figure 1A). The distance between the PIP joint and the origin of the branch was regular and of a repetitive pattern, which is similar in the index, middle, ring, and little fingers (Braga-Silva et al., 2002). The distance is 14–19 mm with a mean of 16 mm proximal to the PIP joint line, and the mean diameter of the branches is 0.3 mm (range 0.2–0.4 mm) at its origin. These studies are a fundamental basis of our technique.

caption.p: (A) The diagram shows that the proper digital artery (PDA) gives off the first dorsal branch (FDB). The FDB further gives off the reverse sub-branch (RSB). (B) A 21-year-old man sustained a crush injury on the volar aspect of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the left middle finger with flexor tendon exposure. The defect was 2 × 2.3 cm in size. (C) A reverse homodigital island flap, 2.4 × 2.7 cm in size, on the dorsum of the proximal phalanx.

sec.p: Various techniques have been reported in the literature. Abdominal (Urushidate et al., 2010), cross finger (Fejjal et al., 2008; Megerle et al., 2008), and cross arm flaps (Fejjal et al., 2006) are useful but have the drawbacks of requiring attachment to the donor sites for 2–3 weeks and possible need for debulking. A reverse dorsal metacarpal flap based on the dorsal metacarpal artery has a long pedicle and the drawback of the technique is a long scar from near the wrist to the middle phalanx (Chen et al., 2010; Keramidas et al., 2004; Lai-jin et al., 2006). The use of free flaps, such as posterior and anterior interosseous free flaps, dorsalis pedis fasciosubcutaneous toe free flaps, and venous flow-through flaps, require microsurgical technique and have a risk of anastomosis failure (Coskunfirat et al., 2010; del Piñal et al., 2005; Hanasono et al., 2010; Ishiko et al., 2009).

A homodigital island flap based on the PDA has the disadvantage of sacrificing one of the PDAs (Anne et al., 2009; Takeishi et al., 2006). The reverse axial adipofascial flaps from the laterodigital and dorsal metacarpal or digital areas have the advantage of being easy to perform and preserve the digital nerve and artery, but partial distal necrosis and partial loss of the overlying skin graft are concerns (Camporro et al., 2010; Tremolada et al., 1998).

In this article, we introduce our experience of the use of a transposition flap harvested from the dorsum of the proximal phalanx for repairing the defect on the palmar aspect of the PIP joint. The flap is based on the first dorsal branch of the PDA.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: From January 2007 to March 2009, transposition flaps harvested from the dorsum of proximal phalanxes was used from 14 digits of 14 patients (10 men and 4 women). Patients’ mean age at surgery was 33 years (range 18–52 years). The mechanisms of the injuries included crush (n = 13) and third-degree burn (n = 1). Injured fingers included 5 index, 6 middle, 2 ring and 1 little finger. Doppler ultrasound was used to detect the first dorsal branch of the PDA in all cases.

Soft tissue defects ranged in size from 1.2 × 1.7 cm to 2.1 × 2.3 cm (mean 1.7 × 2 cm). Flap size ranged from 1.5 × 1.7 cm to 2.4× 2.7 cm (mean 2 × 2.4 cm). Mean pedicle length was 1.1 cm (range 0.8–1.4 cm). Associated flexor tendon (superficial and/or profundus) defects at the PIP joint were noted in 2 digits. Associated PDA (single and/or both sides) defects were noted in 11 digits. Associated defects of the proper digital nerve (single and/or both sides) were noted in 13 digits (Table 1). All patients underwent surgery 2–9 hours (mean 5 hours) after injury.

fn.p: FT = flexor tendon; PDA = proper digital nerve defect; PDN= proper digital nerve.

sec.p: Patients were selected on the basis of the following: (1) soft tissue defects on the volar aspect of the PIP joint; (2) injuries involving the second and third dorsal branches of the PDA; and (3) patient’s age ≥ 18 years. Patients were excluded if they had (1) concomitant injuries to the dorsal or volar aspects of the proximal phalanx that precluded the use of the donor site; (2) injuries to the course of the PDA and its first dorsal branch at the pedicle site; (3) active infection in the digit; and (4) no Doppler sound heard at the location of the first dorsal branch.

sec.title: Surgical technique
sec.p: Surgery was performed under axillary block with pneumatic tourniquet control and with loupe magnification. After careful debridement (Figure 1B), the flap was marked on the dorsum of the proximal phalanx in the same finger. The flap pattern was dependent on the pattern of the defect (Figure 1C). The pivot point was designed at the radial or ulnar lateral border of the proximal phalanx, 16 mm proximal to the PIP joint line at the site of origin of the first dorsal branch from the PDA. Doppler ultrasound was used to confirm the location of the branch.

The incision was made along each border of the flap. When raising the distal half of the flap, preservation of 1 or 2 veins and the subcutaneous tissue was critical for digital venous return (Figure 2A, B). During elevation of the proximal half of the flap, care was taken to leave the paratenon undisturbed to ensure free gliding of the tendon. Thereafter, the pedicle was dissected distally and laterally to the pivot point. The first dorsal branch could be visualized under magnification loupes. The subcutaneous tissue was undermined along the branch. In order to maintain continuity of the reverse sub-branch of the first dorsal branch and have a sufficient venous return, at least 5 mm width of subcutaneous tissue distal to the dorsal branch should be harvested with the pedicle. The area of subcutaneous tissue could be determined after looking at the first dorsal branch. In order to avoid compression after transfer, a strip of skin over the pedicle could be harvested with the pedicle. No attempt was made to visualize the sub-branches. After debridement, the flap was transferred to the recipient site through an open incision (Figure 2C). The donor site was resurfaced with a full-thickness skin graft harvested from the inner aspect of the upper arm. The skin graft was secured with a tie-over bolster dressing, but avoided venous compression at the dorsum of the proximal phalanx.

caption.p: (A) Flap harvesting is complete. The proximal portion (PP) of the flap contains subcutaneous tissue and veins. The distal portion (DP) of the flap only contains cutaneous tissue. (B) Leaving a vein at the donor site for digital venous return. (C) The defect is covered with the flap.

sec.p: In this series, the associated flexor tendon defect at the PIP joint was reconstructed with a graft harvested from the palmaris longus. The associated PDA defect was reconstructed with a vein graft harvested from the volar aspect of the wrist. The associated defect of the proper digital nerve was repaired directly in 1 digit and repaired with a graft from the sural nerve in 13 digits, respectively.

sec.title: Postoperative treatment
sec.p: After surgery, the hand was placed above heart level to reduce venous congestion. The flap and digital circulation was monitored by visual inspection of the tissue colour and capillary refilling for at least 7 days (Suzuki et al., 2008). A splint was applied to promote graft survival for 7 days. In the case with tendon, nerve, and PDA repairs, the PIP joint was splinted at full extension for an additional 3 weeks. Active range-of-motion exercises were initiated thereafter. Tenolysis was performed in 2 digits at 4 months after tendon repair.

sec.title: Evaluation of outcomes
sec.p: Ten days after surgery, the surviving flap and digit displayed warmth, good capillary refill, and pink colour. Active range of motion (ROM) of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP), PIP, and DIP joints was measured by a goniometer and compared with the opposite side (Figure 3A, B, C). Scar pain at the donor and recipient sites were evaluated using the patients’ self-reported assessments. Functional outcomes were assessed using the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) questionnaire (Hudak et al., 1996), which consists mainly of a 30-item disability/symptom scale, scored 0 (no disability) to 100 (most severe disability).

caption.p: Result at 24 months after flap transfer. (A) Donor site. (B) Recipient site and digital extension. (C) Flexion.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The postoperative courses of patients were uneventful and all flaps completely survived. Mild venous congestion of the flap was observed in 3 digits, which was relieved by removal of several stitches and the tie-over dressing. Wound infection did not occur in this series.

All 14 patients were reviewed. At final follow-up of 24–29 months (mean 26 months), hyperpigmentation at the donor site was reported in 8 (60%) of the digits. The ROM arcs of the MCP, PIP, and DIP joints were 84° (range 75–91°), 86° (range 65–100°), and 54° (range 32–80°), respectively. Mean ROM arcs of the same joints of the opposite hand were 88° (range 83–95°), 110° (range 95–112°), and 75° (range 63–88°), respectively. Mean ROM arcs of the MCP, PIP, and DIP joints of the injured sides reached 95%, 78%, and 72% of those of the contralateral sides, respectively (Fig 4A, B, C, E, F). All scars on the donor and recipient sites were painless. The average DASH survey scores were 9.8 (range 3–19) for disability/symptom scale.

caption.p: A 52-year-old woman had a crush injury on the volar aspect of the proximal interphalangeal joint and the distal portion of the proximal phalanx. (A) The two PDAs and the second and third dorsal branches were injured at the level. In this setting, these branches cannot be used as a pedicle. The defect is 1.2 × 1.4 cm in size. (B) A reverse homodigital island flap, 1.5 × 1.7 cm in size, based on the first dorsal branch is marked on the dorsum of the proximal phalanx. (C) Flap coverage was achieved. (D) The flap at 27 months after surgery. (E) The donor site and extension of the index finger. (F) Flexion.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Many surgical techniques have been proposed for soft-tissue defects on the palmar aspect of the PIP joint. A free mini-groin flap, free posterior or anterior interosseous flap, free thenar flap, free toe partial pulp flap, and free arterialized venous flap (Coskunfirat et al., 2010; Garg et al., 2007; Ishiko et al., 2009; Kong et al., 2008; Lee et al., 2002; Tare et al., 2009) can be used for small to large defects and are associated with minimal donor site morbidities. However, these techniques usually have the drawbacks of often using a two-team approach, requiring microsurgical technique, long operating time, high risk of flap loss, and requiring further debulking.

Various heterodigital flaps have been reported in the literature. The use of a Littler flap can provide a large skin paddle with glabrous and sensate skin, but results in a long scar on the donor finger and loss of partial finger pulp sensation (Littler, 1952). In our selected cases, sensory reconstruction was not important for hand function. The reverse heterodigital neurovascular island flap harvested from the middle phalanx of the adjacent uninjured finger (Adani et al., 2005) is indicated for a large pulp defect, as the pulp is important for sensation. However, the pedicle dissection can be cumbersome and donor finger morbidities are considerable.

The transposition flap described in the present study can be harvested from the MCP joint line to the PIP joint line, between the midlateral lines. The flap size is usually sufficient for covering a volar defect at the PIP joint. However, harvesting the flap extending to the MCP joint should be avoided, as scar contracture that restricts MCP joint flexion is a concern (Onishi et al., 2006).

In the present study, we used a Doppler probe to detect the branch. If there is no Doppler sound heard, alternative treatment such as use of a reverse-cross finger flap or homodigital island flap should be considered. If either the ulnar or radial PDA can be selected as the artery supplying the flap, we primarily select the side closest to the defect to obtain a short flap pedicle. Otherwise, the larger PDA should be selected, i.e., the ulnar PDA of the index and middle fingers and the radial PDA of the ring and little fingers.

The flap pedicle can be designed from the origin of the first dorsal branch to the base of the flap. In order to permit sufficient venous drainage, the pedicle width should not be less than 5 mm (Chang et al., 2005; Chen et al., 2010; Takeishi et al., 2006).

According to our clinical observation in this cohort, the first dorsal branch of the PDA initially courses dorso-distally. The angle between the branch and PDA ranged from 50° to 78° (mean 64°) at the bifurcation in the lateral plane. The branch further divides into 2 to 5 (mean 3) sub-branches 2–4 mm (mean 3 mm) distal to the bifurcation. At least 1 sub-branch travels dorso-proximally, which is called the reverse sub-branch (Figure 1A). A similar arterial pattern is also demonstrated in the literature (Braga-Silva et al., 2002; Feng et al., 2011). According to our study, the maximal length of the trunk of the first dorsal branch was 4 mm and the minimal angle of the bifurcation was 50°. Based on our experience, if the distal edge of the pedicle is 4 mm distal to the bifurcation and the incision of the edge is designed transverse to the digit, both the first dorsal branch and its reverse sub-branch could be included in the pedicle and its subcutaneous tissues (Figure 5); thus, the continuity of the reverse sub-branch could be maintained. However, any attempt to explore the sub-branch should be avoided, as there is a possibility of injury to the small vessel (Yang et al., 2001).

caption.p: On the subcutaneous plane, the distal incision should be made transversely for maintenance of continuity of the flexor digitorum brevis and reverse sub-branch.

sec.p: The indication for the use of our technique is repair of a soft tissue defect on the palmar aspect of the PIP joint, especially when the second and third dorsal branches of the PDA cannot be used. The contraindications are injuries to the branch, pedicle, or donor site.

According to previous anatomic studies and our experience, we believe the flap has good vascularity. Other advantages of our technique includes similar donor flap thickness to the recipient site, a single-stage operation, preservation of the PDA, and possible early mobilization of the finger unless there are associated tendon, nerve, and PDA injuries. The disadvantages include a limited flap size and pedicle length, slightly inferior aesthetic appearance of the donor and recipient sites, and possible anatomic variations.
